bibl.title: Letter from James Carroll to Robert M. O'Reilly, August 29, 1906

div1.p: Carroll writes about the Yellow Fever Board's determination to investigate the mosquito theory. Carroll claims that he first proposed Board inoculate themselves. Included is an apparent draft, with autograph notations, and a final copy of the same letter.

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to Robert M. O'Reilly, August 29, 1906

WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
August 29, 1906.

To the Surgeon General,
U. S. Army.
General:

Referring to the notes for Memorandum dated August 23, 1906,
I beg to invite attention to the following facts which are in-
correctly stated in the second paragraph on page 1.

The final determination to investigate the mosquito theory
was arrived at during an informal meeting of the Board (Dr. Agra-
monte being absent) at Columbia Barracks on the evening before
Dr. Reed's departure for the United States early in August 1901.
This subject had been a matter for daily discussion, pro and con,
at our quarters, in the laboratory and, elsewhere, and as Dr. Reed,
Dr. Lazear and myself were quartered at the hospital, Columbia
Barracks, and ate at the same table there was constant opportunity
for discussion of the various phases of the subject in which we
were all intensely interested. Indeed the four members of the
board had previously discussed the mosquito theory with Drs. Durham
and Myers, with one another and with Dr. Charles Finlay whom they
visited for the purpose of discussing the mosquito theory and
ascertaining what data he might have to offer in support of it.

The proposal to submit ourselves to inoculation was made by
myself, twice, before it was brought up by Dr. Reed, for the first
time, at the meeting above mentioned, where it was finally decided
upon by actual vote.

As I know the above statements to be absolutely true and as
I was an actual participant in the work and in the interviews
mentioned by me, I feel bound to invite attention to statements
that constitute a veritable contradiction of my written and oral
statements made at various times from actual knowledge of the oc-
currences themselves.
Very respectfully,
(Sgd) JAMES CARROLL,

1st Lieut., Asst. Surgeon, U.S.A.
Curator, Army Medical Museum.
